citation.article-title: Streptococcus henryi sp. nov. and Streptococcus caballi sp. nov., isolated from the hindgut of horses with oligofructose-induced laminitis.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Streptococcus henryi sp. nov.
Streptococcus henryi [hen.ry′i. N.L. gen. n. henryi named in honour of Dr Dick Peter Henry (AM) (1924–2003), a highly respected Australian veterinarian and microbiologist].
Cells are Gram-positive, non-motile ovoids, typically occurring in pairs or short chains.
When grown anaerobically for 24 h on sheep blood agar, colonies are round, flat, shiny, 2 mm in diameter, off-white in colour and exhibit α-haemolysis.
Cells are facultatively anaerobic and catalase-negative.
Cells react to streptococcal group D antisera and are able to grow in the presence of 40 % bile and 0.016 % potassium tellurite, but do not grow in the presence of 6.5 % NaCl.

In API 20 Strep and Rapid ID32 Strep kits, cells are able to produce acid from starch, glycogen, inulin, lactose, maltose, mannitol, melibiose, methyl β-d-glucopyranoside, pullulan, sucrose and trehalose, but not from d-arabinose, l-arabinose, cyclodextrin, melezitose, raffinose, ribose, sorbitol or tagatose.
Cells do not produce acetoin (Voges–Proskauer-negative) or hydrolyse arginine or hippurate, but do hydrolyse aesculin.

Positive for alanyl-phenylalanyl-proline arylamidase, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, β-glucosidase and leucine aminopeptidase, but negative for N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, alkaline phosphatase, β-glucuronidase, glycyl tryptophan arylamidase, β-mannosidase, pyrrolidonyl arylamidase and urease.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 38.7 mol%.
The type strain, 126T (=ATCC BAA-1484T =DSM 19005T), was isolated from the caecum of a horse with oligofructose-induced laminitis.
